HARVESTING AND POSTHARVEST HANDLING

Pods are harvested at young or immature stage which is the common preference of consumers. Harvested pods are packed in any locally available packaging material. Damaged pods caused by diseases, insects or mechanical means are separated from marketable pods. However, pods with lesser damage can be used as fresh cut produce.

Subjective and objective types of indices are used in harvesting pods. Harvesting is done as follows: 

  1. Harvest the young and tender pods 7-10 days after flowering or 45-50 days after crop emergence. 

  2. To avoid over maturity and to allow producing more flowers, harvest the pods 2-3 days. This will also prolong the productive days of the crop. 

  3. Manually harvest the pods by holding the stem end before twisting it free. 

  4. To avoid wilting, and weight loss, harvest during the cooler times of the days. 

  5. Keep the harvested pods in shaded area.

  6. Pre-sort harvested pods.

Sorting and storing. When sorting, the following should be done:

  1. Sort the pods based on the marketability and the consumer’s demand. 

  2. Pack the marketable pods in polyethylene bags. 

  3. Remove the damaged part caused by pests to convert the produce into fresh cut and pack in small plastic bags. This will minimize the postharvest losses.

   

There are three ways to prolong the shelf life of pods:

  1. Pack pods in perforated polyethylene bag which may last for 3 days under room condition. 

  2. Dip the harvested pods in coconut water for 1 minute. 

  3. Cover or wrap the green pods with moist cloth to maintain freshness for 2-3 days. 

 

Green pods also last up to 1 week by storing in a cool (7-10 °C) dry place. 

When pods are used for planting materials:

  1. Sun-dry the pods for 3-4 days depending on the weather condition. 

  2. Thresh the pods by beating with stick or by the use of the feet. 

  3. After threshing and cleaning, dry for 2-3 days to decrease the moisture content to 10-12% before storage. 

  4. Store seeds in airtight containers with 2 pieces of naphthalene balls per a kilo of seeds. 

  5. Label the container.
